name: Kalasin
description: Home to the famous Pha Praewa silk, known as the 'Queen of Silk'. This intricate textile combines weaving and embroidery techniques unique to the Phu Thai ethnic group, traditionally worn as a shoulder cloth (Sabai).

name: Khon Kaen
description: The center of the Isan silk trade and a World Craft City for Ikat (Mudmee). Khon Kaen silk is recognized for its sharp, precise patterns and the 'Kaen Koon' signature pattern which symbolizes the Golden Shower tree.

name: Nakhon Ratchasima
description: Also known as Korat, this province produces heavy, durable silk. The unique 'Hang Karok' technique uses twisted yarn to create a shimmering, two-tone effect, while the 'Korat Monogram' features the Korat cat.

name: Buriram
description: Famous for 'Phu Akkani' or volcanic soil-dyed fabric. Locals use the iron-rich soil from extinct volcanoes to dye cotton and silk, resulting in a beautiful, soft terracotta orange hue representing the land's spirit.

name: Sakon Nakhon
description: Renowned for 'Kram' (Indigo) dyed textiles. The natural fermentation process creates deep, lasting blue shades. The fabric often carries a natural fragrance from the indigo plant and is believed to protect against UV rays.

name: Udon Thani
description: Inspired by the Ban Chiang archaeological site, Udon Thani silk often features swirls and geometric patterns mimicking ancient pottery. The 'Khid' weaving technique is also prominent here.

name: Chaiyaphum
description: Known for 'Ban Khwao' silk, considered some of the finest in Thailand. The weaving produces incredibly smooth execution of Mudmee patterns with a distinct focus on natural simplicity and elegance.

name: Nong Khai
description: Situated on the Mekong River, the patterns here are heavily influenced by the 'Naga' (mythical serpent). The 7-headed Naga pattern is a signature, symbolizing protection and prosperity.

name: Loei
description: With a cooler climate, Loei is famous for its cotton and silk blends. The specific 'Dok Fai Ban' (Blooming Cotton) pattern reflects the province's natural flora and mountainous terrain.

name: Bueng Kan
description: Thailand's newest province creates distinct identity through 'Mak Beng' patterns, inspired by offering bowls used in Buddhist rituals. They also utilize natural dyes from the Mekong mud.

name: Nakhon Phanom
description: Home to the Tai Yor ethnic group, creating the 'Muk' fabric. This involves a supplementary warp technique that creates geometric diamonds and squares, often used for official vestments.

name: Mukdahan
description: Influenced by multiple tribes, the 'Kaew Mukda' pattern combines five auspicious designs: Naga, lantern, flower, and geometric forms, representing the diversity of the province.

name: Yasothon
description: Famous for the 'Look Wai' (Rattan Fruit) pattern. The designs are often small, repetitive, and rythmic, reflecting the fun and energetic spirit of the Rocket Festival (Bun Bang Fai).

name: Amnat Charoen
description: A province with strong Buddhist roots. The 'Kho Khing' pattern looks like ginger hooks or keys, symbolizing stability and hooking onto good fortune and mindfulness.

name: Ubon Ratchathani
description: The creator of the 'Kab Bua' (Lotus Petal) cloth. This national heritage fabric combines four techniques: Ikhat (Mudmee), Khid (Pattern), Jok (Embroidery), and Plain weave into one piece.

name: Si Sa Ket
description: Home to 'Pha Saew', a silk treated with 'Maklua' (Ebony fruit) to turn it deep black, then embroidered with colorful silk threads. It is durable and smells of nature.

name: Surin
description: Influenced by Khmer ancestry, Surin produces 'Hol' and 'Amprum' silk. These are extremely fine, tightly woven fabrics with intricate micro-patterns, often using natural dyes.

name: Roi Et
description: Produces the 'Lai Saket' pattern, named after the provincial capital. It represents the town's history and consists of five sub-patterns woven together in vibrant colors.

name: Maha Sarakham
description: The 'Soi Dok Mak' pattern is the signature here. It resembles the flower of the betel nut palm. It requires high precision in tying the Mudmee threads to create small, detailed repeating flowers.

name: Nong Bua Lamphu
description: Famous for 'Khid Mai' or Silk Khid. The patterns often feature the 'Lotus' (Bua) paying homage to the province's name. It combines the raised texture of Khid with the smoothness of silk.
